awd_titl_txt: III: Medium: Collaborative Research: Human-Computer Graph Exploration and Tele-Discovery
awd_abstract_narration:
The amount of information available to individuals today is enormous and rapidly increasing. People are constantly making sense of the world: scientists learning the literature in an unfamiliar field; analysts spotting abnormal activities in computer networks; and patients understanding their symptoms. From a user's perspective, the main issue is not about storage, or computing power, or large scale data processing. It is more about how to best amplify his or her limited cognition power to make sense of a large data corpus via "natural" interactive exploration. This project will undertake the challenge of computer-human interactive exploration of information-rich billion-scale network datasets. These include online social networks (who is connected to whom), online auctions (who is buying what), and intelligence analysis of communication patterns and network traffic. It will blend computer-human interaction principles and decomposable visualizations with new scalable exploration techniques that are driven by information-theoretic measures. Specifically, it will design and develop a prototype system, in which users will gradually build up an understanding of billion-scale network datasets. This research could fundamentally change how people make sense of data in many domains like scientific literature, cybersecurity, and consumer decision making. The findings could increase education effectiveness, rate of scientific discovery, and enable more literate, knowledgeable, and intelligent citizens.

This project will combine multiple novel ideas synergistically, organized into four inter-related research thrusts: (1) Adaptive Local Exploration using Minimum Description Length principles (MDL), KL divergence and Combinatorial Discrepancy. (2) Pattern Tele-Discovery & Global Summarization via algorithmic teleportation tools. These will include mechanisms for querying, discovering, linking, and visualizing multi-attributed time-evolving network patterns. (3) Scalable Data Models & Algorithms to support the interactivity demands of the previous thrusts. The proposed tools will address storage layouts via Egonet Edge Partitions and distributed sparse and persistent multidimensional sorted maps. (4) The researchers will continually conduct multi-stage evaluations in key domains, working with users throughout the entire development process. These will include iterative interface development via in-person user studies, virtual lab studies, and longitudinal field trials. For further information see the project web site at:
http://poloclub.gatech.edu/human-computer-telediscovery/
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
This research project developed scalable, interactive novel tools that enable people to make sense of information-rich large-scale network datasets, in domains from scientific literature, cybersecurity, and consumer decision making. This research blended computer-human interaction principles and decomposable visualizations with new scalable exploration techniques, allowing users to gradually build up an understanding of the data, and amplified their discovery power for making sense of the full-scale data corpora.

This research has resulted in a large number of significant research results (34 publications in total), practical deployments, and 8 open-source tools and systems that are immediately available for people to use, such as:

* Breakthrough Web-based Graph Sensemaking Systems: we have deployed and integrated the Argo Lite visualization tool into Georgia Tech's Data and Visual Analytics course. To date, it has been used by over 5,000 undergraduate and graduate students. Developed as a web application that runs in all modern web browsers, anyone can readily use it without any special hardware or software installation. Argo Scholar (https://poloclub.github.io/argo-scholar/) extends Argo Lite to provide people with real-time access to Semantic Scholar's live data of over 200 million papers, enabling users to generate personalized literature exploration results through flexible, incremental exploration, a common and effective method for researchers to discover relevant work. Our tool allows users to easily share their literature exploration results as a URL.

* Novel Interactive Scalable Graph Query Tools: we developed (1) fundamental new ways for people to more easily and quickly construct graph queries without writing complex code (VISAGE); (2) new measures based on information theory that leverage user interest and surprise to help user explore large graph data and find interestingly-relevant content; and (3) interactive visual exploration techniques that help security analysts more easily make sense of large number of results (VIGOR) over 11,000 incidents. Our research inspires researchers to rethink how the fields on data mining, machine learning, human-computer interaction, and visualization may work more closely together, to innovate and create new breeds of methods and tools that are simultaneously interactive, scalable, and easy to use.

* Breakthrough Network-based Learning Systems: we extended our graph-based thinking to innovate new ways for students, practitioners, and researchers to learn about modern deep learning techniques, which can be hard for beginners to take their first steps due to their internal complexity. We developed CNN Explainer (https://poloclub.github.io/cnn-explainer/), an interactive visualization tool designed for non-experts to learn and examine convolutional neural networks (CNNs), a foundational deep learning model architecture. We also developed GAN Lab (https://poloclub.github.io/ganlab/), the first interactive visualization tool designed for non-experts to learn and experiment with Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs), a popular class of complex deep learning models. Core to both tools, they use a network-based representation to visualize and explain the complex interactions between the various components within the models. Both tools went viral on social media when released, and have since received close to 6,000 and 1,200 GitHub "stars" respectively.

This project has supported and trained multiple PhD and undergraduate students, and formed the foundations for five PhD dissertations. The student researchers were recognized by multiple prestigious PhD fellowship awards (NASA, Google, JPMorgan AI (two)), two PhD dissertation thesis awards, two Outstanding Undergraduate Research Awards, two Outstanding Undergraduate Research Awards, an Outstanding Freshman Award, and an Outstanding Senior Award. This project's research was also recognized by a Best Demo Award Honorable Mention at SIGMOD'17, and a Best Poster Award Honorable Mention Award at VIS'21. A former student is now a tenure-track professor.


Last Modified: 03/13/2022
Modified by: Duen Horng Chau
